title: What were the original beliefs of the ancient Romans about the afterlife and how did they view the concept of divinity and the role of political leaders in religion?
first_phrase: This text explores the spiritual beliefs of ancient Rome, particularly regarding the merging of religious and political roles in the figures of consuls and other leaders. The Flamen Dialis, dedicated to Jupiter, was considered a living symbol of divinity. In contrast to the elaborate afterlife beliefs in other cultures, the original Roman view was simple and practical, with death seen as a state of neither joy nor suffering. The influence of Epicurean philosophy reflects this focus on realism. As the text concludes, it considers the enduring impact of these beliefs on imperial cults and beyond.
content: Alle origini, può dirsi che il problema dell'oltretomba come problema « religioso » al Romano medio non si pose nemmeno. Virilmente realista, alieno da ogni vana speculazione, chiuso alle agitazioni dello sperare, del temere e del credere, di ciò il Romano non si interessava. Egli era capace di guardare con occhio chiaro e calmo lo stesso nulla. Non aveva bisogno di prospettive oltremondane per dare alla propria vita un senso e un'in- tima norma. Cosi la concezione originaria dell'oltretomba a Roma fu soprattutto quella di una notte, di uno stato senza gaudio né sofferenza: perpetua nox dormienda — dice Ca- tone; ultra neque curae neque gaudi locum esse — sono le parole attribuite allo stesso Cesare. Il successo della filosofia epicurea ripresa da Lucrezio a Roma, a tale riguardo, è si- gnificativo. Esso non denota un materialismo ma, di nuovo, un realismo.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the ancient Roman concept of the afterlife was marked by a realist approach, rejecting mysticism and mythology. The success of the Epicurean philosophy and its naturalistic explanations for death served as a tool to alleviate the fear and terror of death. The Romans viewed the human being as a complex entity, with various forces including those associated with ancestry and race. Understanding these concepts can offer insight into the ancient Roman worldview and approach to life, death, and the afterlife.
